channel.title: BBC News - Home

item.title: Face coverings U-turn for England’s secondary schools
item.description: Pupils will have to wear masks in school corridors in local lockdown areas of England, after the government reversed its guidance.

item.title: Ofqual chief Sally Collier steps down after exams chaos
item.description: The head of England's exams regulator quits after the chaos of this year's A-level and GCSE results.

item.title: Harry Maguire given suspended sentence in Greece
item.description: Manchester United captain Harry Maguire is given a suspended sentence of 21 months and 10 days after his arrest on the Greek island of Mykonos.

item.title: Jacob Blake: Wisconsin black man 'will need miracle' to walk again
item.description: Jacob Blake's spinal cord was severed when he was shot by police on Sunday night in Wisconsin.

item.title: RNC 2020: The speakers and schedule for day two of Trump's Republican convention
item.description: The first lady and two of Donald Trump's children will speak - the president will be back again.

item.title: Weather: Storm Francis lashes UK with gusts reaching almost 80mph
item.description: Homes are flooded, campers rescued and road and rail travel disrupted amid severe weather warnings.

item.title: Lionel Messi hands in Barcelona transfer request
item.description: Legendary Barcelona forward Lionel Messi asks to leave the club this summer.

item.title: US Postal Service: Three states sue Trump government
item.description: Hawaii, New Jersey and New York are suing the Trump administration over alleged "partisan meddling".

item.title: Virgin Atlantic wins backing for £1.2bn rescue deal
item.description: A deal with creditors will secure the airline's future for the next 18 months and save 6,500 jobs.

item.title: Coronavirus: Nottinghamshire woman, 75, 'first positive test within UK'
item.description: The woman is also believed by scientists to be the first in the UK to die after contracting Covid-19.

item.title: Boris Johnson 'cannot believe' BBC Proms decision
item.description: The Prime Minister accuses the UK of "cringing embarrassment" about its history and traditions.

item.title: Eat Out to Help Out discount used 64m times in three weeks
item.description: The Treasury says its scheme, which gives diners 50% off in August, is helping to protect 1.8m jobs.

item.title: Nearly 50,000 salmon escaped from storm-damaged fish farm
item.description: Damage to mooring ropes at the farm near Campbeltown during Storm Ellen resulted in the fish breaking free.

item.title: The Papers: PM 'forced to backtrack' on masks and 'Harry's shame'
item.description: The PM's U-turn on face masks in schools and Harry Maguire being found guilty of assault make the front pages.

item.title: Scottish farmers star in Pharrell Williams and Jay-Z video
item.description: The Aberdeenshire couple initially thought the request for help was a hoax but they have now found fame.

item.title: Storm Francis: In pictures
item.description: Pictures show the effects of Storm Francis's strong winds and heavy rain in the UK.

item.title: DFS reports jump in sofa sales as shoppers sit it out
item.description: DFS reports a £100m rise in sales as people splash out after spending more time at home.

item.title: ‘Black people have been through a lot this year’
item.description: How the combination of lockdown and all the events surrounding Black Lives Matter have affected the mental health of African Americans.

item.title: The Little Princess Trust: 'Do you miss having long hair?'
item.description: Two girls who have been involved with a charity that uses donated hair talk of their experiences.

item.title: Coronavirus: How do you look after someone with Covid-19?
item.description: BBC Health Correspondent Laura Foster explains what you should do when taking care of someone who has coronavirus in your home.

item.title: Music ban 'kiss of death for restaurant ambience'
item.description: Restaurateurs and hoteliers in Scotland are calling for a ban on background music to be lifted.

item.title: Italian monks in Wales on London to Ireland walk
item.description: Dressed in full monastic robes, they fast as they walk, drinking only water during the day.

item.title: Cars filmed on A10 near Cambridge speeding and crashing into each other
item.description: Video posted on social media shows three cars repeatedly colliding before being abandoned.

item.title: BTS's Dynamite shatters YouTube records - and heads for UK number one
item.description: Dynamite is the first video in YouTube history to gain over 100 million views in a 24-hour period.

item.title: Israeli youths unearth 1,100-year-old gold coins from Abbasid era
item.description: Volunteers at an archaeological dig find 425 coins, enough to buy a mansion when they were buried.

item.title: H-ABC: Mothers raising awareness of rare disease
item.description: Three mothers are raising awareness of H-ABC, believed to be one of the rarest diseases on the planet.

item.title: Coronavirus: Can I work from home overseas?
item.description: Thinking about setting up a home office abroad? Here's what you need to know.

item.title: Lockdown may have lasting effects on friendships
item.description: Some marginal friendships will by lost, says psychologist, while other deeper ones may need work.

item.title: Mark and Patricia McCloskey: What really went on in St Louis that day?
item.description: A US couple gained instant notoriety for waving guns at protesters. What really happened that day?

item.title: British Army could axe ageing tanks as part of modernisation plans
item.description: Senior Army officers have told the BBC the military may abandon its ageing stock of Challenger 2 tanks.

item.title: Greta Thunberg: What she did during her year-long school break
item.description: The 17-year-old has gone back to education after a year of climate change activism.

item.title: Why are clothing sizes so erratic and can they be fixed?
item.description: New apps use your phone to record your dimensions and recommend what size to buy at shops.

item.title: Notting Hill Carnival: 'We're playing in Brixton this year'
item.description: Channel One have been at every Notting Hill Carnival since 1983 but this year the event is online.

item.title: Hong Kong protest singers fear for their future
item.description: Has the new national security law pulled the plug on Hong Kong's pro-democracy musicians?

item.title: Black Lives Matter in the UK: 'We're still not being heard'
item.description: Protest organisers look back at progress now hashtags aren't trending and marches aren't in the news.

item.title: Coronavirus turns Kenyan classrooms into chicken coops
item.description: Some Kenyan private schools have found new sources of income after they were forced to close.

item.title: Bletchley Park: New crisis for code-breaking hub
item.description: The chief executive of the Bletchley Park Trust says it is struggling to survive.

item.title: Ten countries kept out Covid. But did they win?
item.description: Covid-19 has infected almost every country in the world – apart from 10. So what do they do now?

item.title: Harry Maguire withdrawn from England squad after trial
item.description: Harry Maguire is withdrawn from the England squad after being given a suspended jail sentence in Greece.

item.title: 'He has set the bar like Sachin' - cricket pays tribute to Anderson after 600th wicket
item.description: England's James Anderson becomes the first fast bowler to reach 600 Test wickets.

item.title: England and Pakistan settle for a draw on Anderson's historic day
item.description: England have to settle for a draw in the final Test against Pakistan on the day that James Anderson becomes the first fast bowler to reach 600 Test wickets.

item.title: Man Utd and PSG competing to sign Messi - Wednesday's football gossip
item.description: PSG and Manchester United could sign Lionel Messi, Thiago Silva is set for a Chelsea medical, plus more.

item.title: Premiership leaders Exeter grab late win at Bristol
item.description: Exeter Chiefs score late on to beat second-placed Bristol Bears and move 11 points clear at the top of the Premiership.

item.title: England v Pakistan: James Anderson takes his 600th Test wicket
item.description: James Anderson dismisses Pakistan's Azhar Ali to become the first seam bowler in history to take 600 Test wickets.

item.title: Rodrigo Moreno: Leeds United agree deal to sign Valencia striker
item.description: Leeds United agree a deal to sign Valencia and Spain forward Rodrigo Moreno.

item.title: Coronavirus: Are teachers more at risk of coronavirus?
item.description: Children are at low risk from the disease, but concerns have been raised for teachers.

item.title: Coronavirus: How are European countries reopening schools?
item.description: Children are starting a new school year across Europe. What measures are being put in place?

item.title: Coronavirus: When does the 'eat out to help out scheme' end?
item.description: Thousands of venues have taken part in a discounting scheme to help boost the hospitality industry.

item.title: Coronavirus in the UK: How many confirmed cases are there in your area?
item.description: Key graphics explaining how coronavirus has spread in the UK and the government's response.

item.title: Coronavirus: What tests are available?
item.description: What are the tests for coronavirus, who are they for and how do they work?

item.title: Coronavirus: What are the rules for face masks or face coverings?
item.description: Secondary school pupils must use masks between lessons in Scotland and Northern Ireland - with similar advice in lockdown areas of England from 1 September.

item.title: Coronavirus: How can I find a new job?
item.description: Jobseekers are having a tough time at the moment but some sectors are hiring and support is available.

item.title: Coronavirus: What are the UK travel quarantine rules?
item.description: France and the Netherlands are the latest places from where people must quarantine on arriving in the UK.

item.title: BTec Nationals and Firsts: What went wrong with the grades?
item.description: The BTec First grades have been delayed. What caused the problems with the results?

item.title: Coronavirus cure: What progress are we making on treatments?
item.description: Teams around the world are looking into medicines for Covid-19 and scientists are starting to discover what works.

item.title: Coronavirus: How does Covid-19 test-and-trace work?
item.description: People who have been in close contact with someone found to have Covid-19 are now being traced.

item.title: Coronavirus: Does my child have to return to school?
item.description: Parents are being urged to send their children back to school for the autumn term

item.title: Europe lockdown: New coronavirus rules country by country
item.description: What are European countries doing to control new coronavirus outbreaks?

item.title: Coronavirus: What are the rules around evictions?
item.description: The ban on evictions has been extended, but how do they work?

item.title: Coronavirus: What are the risks of catching it from food packaging?
item.description: Some cases around the world have been linked to packaging on frozen food.

item.title: Coronavirus: What are the UK's travel rules and which countries can you visit?
item.description: New rules mean people entering the UK from certain countries will not have to quarantine.
